DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US will release a list of products that tariffs will be placed on 301 investigations today and China will post their retaliation list later, according to the Editor-in-Chief of Chinese and English editions of the Global Times. (Global Times)

China's Vice Premier Liu He stressed prudent and neutral monetary policy and said that China will keep liquidity reasonably stable. Liu also noted that the country should deepen financial reform in a market-oriented way. (Newswires)

White House Press Secretary Sanders said the US and South Korea have agreed a trade deal in principle. (Newswires)


UK/EU

ECB's Liikanen said EZ inflation is sustainable when ECB's objective can be met without very accommodative monetary policy and added that ECB needs patience as underlying inflation is lower than expected. (Newswires)

ECB’s Makuch said underlying inflation trends show no convincing signs of an upturn. (Newswires)

Brussels is considering a EUR 50bn raid on European Central Bank profits and a plastics tax to plug a hole in its long-term budget after Brexit. (FT)
 

FX

The USD reiterated its credentials as a risk-off currency, strengthening as equities, crude and yields slid. EUR is consolidating around 1.24, having found the air thin near 1.25; a dovish dose of ECB chatter and a fall in the EC’s sentiment gauges kept the EUR offered, while some traders also cited bearish technicals. JPY couldn’t meaningfully test 106.00 and made its way back down to below 105.50 as havens were bid (though CHF was mixed). GBP continued to take its cue from the USD, consolidating around 1.4150, though the range was wide (approx. 1.4070-1.4240). Risk FX (CAD, AUD, NZD) were lower on a stronger buck; for AUD, the 0.77 was breached again which tech folks say opens the way to Fib support around 0.7650; similarly, the USDCAD rose as risk sentiment softened, briefly breaching 1.29 to the upside. EMFX was weaker, taking its lead from the USD.


COMMODITIES

US API weekly crude stocks (23 Mar) 5.321M vs. Exp. -0.300M (Prev. -2.739M). (Newswires)

Saudi Crown Prince said OPEC seeks a 10yr-20yr supply cooperation with Russia as well as other producers, while Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih stated OPEC/Non-OPEC Agreement is not a year by year project. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

North Korean Leader Kim reportedly held a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing. (Nikkei)


US

Fed's Bostic (voter, dovish) said he supports plans to gradually raise interest rates, but uncertainty over how the economy would respond next year to tax cuts and increased government spending could complicate monetary policy. Furthermore, Bostic said the Fed could soon face rising chances that the economy grows faster than forecast and leads to a slightly faster pace of rate rises. (WSJ)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said markets are starting to realise that tariffs are a bargaining chip. (Newswires)

US is to protect its tech sector through emergency law to curb China's takeovers, according to sources. (Newswires)

US Consumer Confidence (Mar) 127.7 vs. Exp. 131.0 (Prev. 130.8, Rev. 130.0). (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Equity futures suffered from a risk-off tone on Tuesday as markets await tariff details from the US, while traders are also keeping an eye out for details of Chinese counter-measures. As a result, defensive stocks outperformed with utilities leading, while the SPX and some sectors, such as consumer cyclicals and financials, weighed. Tech was the notable underperformer, closing over 4% lower, led by Nvidia (NVDA) halting its autonomous car tests, and Facebook (FB) due to ongoing privacy investigations. Also, its competitor Twitter (TWTR) slipped after Citron Research turned negative on the stock. Elsewhere, some auto names were firmer after UBS turned positive on the sector. In late trade the 2600 support level held the E-mini, with stocks seeing a small bounce heading into the close. SPX -1.73% at 2613, NDX -3.2% at 6530, DJI -1.43% at 23856.

Yields were lower by between 4-6bps across the curve on Tuesday, as risk-off sentiment spurred a Treasury bid. As was the case on Monday, much of the action was focussed in the belly, where yields on 10s breached 2.80% falling to six-week lows. There was flattening in 2s5s, 2s10s, 2s30s by between 5-6bps, though 5s30s widened modestly at settlement. The US Treasury sold $35bln 5-year notes, tailing by 0.3bps – the fifth straight tail at a 5s auction. Cover was slightly higher than recent averages, while higher indirect participation was encouraging. Some remain impressed that the auction performed as it did given the bumper supply this week (slightly short of $300bln including bills). US 10-year T-note futures (m18) settled 14 ticks higher at 120-29.

US MARKET WRAP: Markets await tariff announcement as risk off tone arises
content:
* SNAPSHOT: USD up, Treasuries up, Stocks down, oil down
* REAR-VIEW: Risk-off amid thin news/data docket, generally dovish ECB speak.
* AHEAD: China tariff details, API inventories.

* EQUITIES: SPX -1.73% at 2613 , NDX -3.2% at 6530 , DJI -1.43% at 23856
* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): -2.13%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -0.41%, ENERGY (XLE): -1.25%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -2.09%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -1.48%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -1.78%, MATERIALS (XLB): -1.25%, TECH (XLK): -4.13%, TELECOMS (XTL): +0.29%, UTLITIES (XLU): +1.41%. 

Equity futures suffered from a risk-off tone on Tuesday as markets await tariff details from the US, while traders are also keeping an eye out for details of Chinese counter-measures. As a result, defensive stocks outperformed with utilities leading, while the SPX and some sectors, such as consumer cyclicals and financials, weighed. Tech was the notable underperformer, closing over 4% lower, led by Nvidia (NVDA) halting its autonomous car tests, and Facebook (FB) due to ongoing privacy investigations. Also, its competitor Twitter (TWTR) slipped after Citron Research turned negative on the stock. Elsewhere, some auto names were firmer after UBS turned positive on the sector. In late trade the 2600 support level held the E-mini, with stocks seeing a small bounce heading into the close.

TREASURIES: US 10-YEAR T-NOTE FUTURES (M18) SETTLED 14 TICKS HIGHER AT 120-29. Yields were lower by between 4-6bps across the curve on Tuesday, as risk-off sentiment spurred a Treasury bid. As was the case on Monday, much of the action was focussed in the belly, where yields on 10s breached 2.80% falling to six-week lows. There was flattening in 2s5s, 2s10s, 2s30s by between 5-6bps, though 5s30s widened modestly at settlement. The US Treasury sold $35bln 5-year notes, tailing by 0.3bps – the fifth straight tail at a 5s auction. Cover was slightly higher than recent averages, while higher indirect participation was encouraging. Some remain impressed that the auction performed as it did given the bumper supply this week (slightly short of $300bln including bills).

FOREX: DXY +0.4% HEADING INTO APAC. There was little by way of first-tier releases or speakers on the slate, leaving the USD to trade-off broader sentiment. On Tuesday, the buck reiterated its credentials as a risk-off currency, strengthening as equities, crude and yields slid. EUR is consolidating around 1.24, having found the air thin near 1.25; a dovish dose of ECB chatter and a fall in the EC’s sentiment gauges kept the EUR offered, while some traders also cited bearish technicals. JPY couldn’t meaningfully test 106.00, and made its way back down to c.105.50 as havens were bid (though CHF was mixed). GBP continued to take its cue from the USD, consolidating around 1.4150, though the range was wide (approx. 1.4070-1.4240). Risk FX (CAD, AUD, NZD) were lower on a stronger buck; for AUD, the 0.77 was breached again which tech folks say opens the way to Fib support around 0.7650; similarly, the USDCAD rose as risk sentiment softened, briefly breaching 1.29 to the upside. EMFX was weaker, taking its lead from the USD.

COMMODITIES:  WTI crude futures settle 30c lower at USD 65.25; Brent crude futures settle lower by 1c at USD 70.11.
Trading largely flat ahead of API’s weekly inventory data, released after market close. The Street is expecting a headline crude draw 0.3mln. Genscape was said to forecast a 2.2mln build at Cushing. Meanwhile, analysts expect products to drawdown in the week, with distillate stocks seen declining by 1.6mln, and gasoline seen drawing by 2mln. Iraq’s SOMO again talked-up compliance with OPEC’s future decisions, adding that the country’s oil output will not exceed 3.426mln bpd in March. Also on the jawboning front, Saudi Arabia stated that the OPEC/Non-OPEC agreement is not a year-by-year project. It added that OPEC was seeking a 10-20 year supply cooperation with Russia and other partner countries, and a broad agreement has been reached around this, though details still need to be worked out.

CENTRAL BANK SPEAK: The tone of ECB speak on Tuesday was mostly dovish. Focus seemed to be on ECB’s Liikanen, normally a centrist, said EZ inflation would be considered sustainable when ECB’s objective can be met without very accommodative policy. Similarly, Makuch followed saying underlying inflation trends show no convincing signs of an upturn. Some of the more hawkish members of the ECB also spoke; Vasiliasskus said he expects more detailed talks on policy changes in June, and agreed with the market pricing for a mid-2019 hike. ECB’s Novotny also took a hawkish tone, and said he believes asset purchases should be removed gradually, adding if things continue they will be able to reduce asset purchases significantly and that they must decide by summer. Fedspeak was slightly easier on Tuesday, with the only notable comments from Bostic (voter), who said he wants to see gradual rate hikes, but noted that uncertainty over how the economy would respond next year to tax cuts and increased government spending could complicate monetary policy. Elsewhere, Bostic said the Fed could soon face rising chances that the economy grows faster than forecast and leads to a slightly faster pace of rate rises.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 35bln of 5-year notes at 1300 EDT/1800 BST
content:
• THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: Ex-bills, the US Treasury will sell USD 109bln this week in 2-year (USD 30bln, Monday), 5-year notes (USD 35bln, Tuesday), 7-year (USD 29bln, Wednesday), as well as a 2-year FRN (USD 15bln, Wednesday). With USD 66.3bln maturing at end-month settlement, net supply is implied at USD 42.7bln, according to TD Securities.
  • 2-YEAR AUCTION REVIEW: Monday’s auction of 2-year notes saw a tail of 0.4bps, though cover was slightly stronger than the prior. Perhaps the most interesting story was that it was digested well considering the Treasury + Bills issuance this week is set to come in just shy of $300bln.
  • 5-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Last month’s 5s auction came in on the screws, though the yield was highest since December 2009; cover, however, was softer than recent averages. In the latest week, dealers trimmed their holdings in the 3-6 year sector by $2.2bln, to $8.2bln. SocGen says that the current 5-year note trades cheap on asset swap compared to older 5s. The bank also suggests that there is no clear set-up going into the auction, and therefore, concession will likely be needed for the issuance to be underwritten smoothly. Elsewhere, the bank cites the size of issuance as a potential headwind, while also noting that 5-year notes haven’t performed particularly well at auction, as of late.


RECENT AUCTION HISTORY (Via TD Securities)

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY recovers from early dip below 89.000 level
content: The Dollar is ending Tuesday’s session firmer vs all G10 rivals to varying degrees, and in part at least on some early month-end buying amidst rebalancing models indicating ‘strong across the board’ demand. The index is off best levels after weaker than forecast Richmond and US Consumer Confidence surveys, but survived an early sub-89.000 test following a low fix vs the Cny and all round Eur gains that may have been fix and/or reserve-related. Stg also suffered vs the single currency, as Eur/Gbp squeezed up towards 0.8800, while Cable reversed sharply from around 1.4240 again to circa 1.4065 before rebounding to the mid-1.4150 area. Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd both continued to retreat from recent peaks, with the former filling some supposed big bidding interest at 0.7700 and the latter down to 0.7260 at one stage. Eur/Usd retreated about a big figure from 1.2475 highs on the back of broadly dovish ECB commentary and softer than expected Eurozone macro releases, but is trying to revisit 1.2400 and Usd/Jpy extended its retracement from fresh 2018 lows hit overnight yesterday (104.56), though pulled up short of the 106.00 handle. Usd/Cad respected a strong downside tech level at 1.2803 amidst some constructive NAFTA news, but the pair topped out just above 1.2900.

subject: Goldman Sachs says equity valuations are not a major risk for equities
content:
• Goldman Sachs Bear/ Bull indicator (ticker: GSBLBR) is currently above 70% - a level normally associated with high risks for equity investors.
  • Goldman Sachs do not believe that this is consistent with an imminent bear market because of the wide spread in the underlying variables. Current very low levels of unemployment and strong growth momentum would normally be associated with other risks - in particular tighter monetary policy, a flatter yield curve and rising core inflation. But these remain subdued and without these risks rising, the prospect of a recession and ‘cyclical’ bear market is low.
  • Structural bear market risks are also modest given the absence of major financial imbalances - or at least the shifting of imbalances away from the private sector to the public sector and central banks.
  • Slower growth and higher rates prospects point to lower risk adjusted returns this year but not a sustained bear market.
  • Valuation is a contributor to the index and is becoming less of a risk. The correction has resulted in a 5.7% de-rating in global equities YTD. The forward consensus PE for the MSCI AC World is back to its 1990 average and below its average ex Tech.
  • Elevated valuations are evident across most asset classes. Equities remain attractively valued relative to bonds (Equity risk premia are still elevated). n High equity valuations are mainly a feature of the US equity market and much of this can be explained by sector exposure and relative ROE.
  • Valuations also need to reflect the impact of share buybacks. The total cash return (the dividend yield plus the buyback yield) has increased in most markets despite collapsing bond yields post the financial crisis.
  • Free cash flow yields have also increased alongside higher P/E ratios. Companies are generating higher cash flow with less traditional capital expenditure making cash flow measures perhaps more important than in the past.
  • .

subject: JPMorgan says buy equities, valuations are below historical average
content:
• S&P 500 is still down ~5% (vs. two weeks ago) and is trading at pre-tax reform levels despite stronger fundamentals (higher organic growth and margin expansion) and favorable flows (corporates are accelerating buyback programs and investors have significantly de-risked). Most of the selling seen over this period has been largely technical (trend-following strategies and option hedging in illiquid market environment), and as such represents a buying opportunity for fundamental investors. Based on consensus EPS estimate for next twelve months, S&P 500 now trades at only ~16x (ex-cash ~15x), which is below 30-year median, see Figure 1. In addition to being cheap in absolute terms (below historical median), valuation looks even cheaper if taken in context of low global interest rates. For instance, over the past 30 years interest rates have averaged almost five times higher than current average global level of ~0.6%, see Figure 2. While the market appears to be overreacting to sequential negative narratives (e.g., inflation scare, rising yields, hawkish Fed, rising deficits), JP Morgan believe strong macro and fundamentals will continue to prevail. In the latest episode, the market’s irrational response to tariffs on potentially $50b of Chinese imports led to investors erasing ~$4 trillion in global market capitalization (~100x total value of goods affected by tariffs). In fact, JP Morgan believe the impact of tariffs will be smaller than indicated by initial ask from the administration (see here) and it could lead to some positives such as greater liberalization of markets, agreements on IP rules, etc. remain constructive on equities and reiterate our S&P 500 price target of 3,000.JP Morgan are also taking the market sell-off to upgrade Technology to Neutral on more favorable technicals, continued strong organic growth, lower USD, rising shareholder payouts, and cheaper valuation.
  • Fundamentals strong with >30% EPS growth over next two years. Since November, S&P 500 consensus 2017-2019 earnings growth has been revised up sharply to 32% (vs. 22%) on back of much lower effective tax rate of 22% (vs. 27%) and stronger sales growth, see Figure 3. In our view, there is still room for estimates to move higher given indirect benefits of tax reform are difficult to model (i.e., the impact of dynamic scoring, rising disposable income, higher business investment). Also, they expect a record year for buybacks and believe consensus ~$500b estimate (vs. $527b in 2017) is underestimating the payout and potential EPS benefit. Based on our estimate, gross buybacks could total ~$800b in 2018 due to repatriation, lower tax policy uncertainty, and record earnings (organic growth and tax benefit expected to drive more than 30% EPS growth during 2017-19).
  • Upgrading Technology to Neutral. The sector should continue to deliver strong double-digit earnings growth on secular trends (e.g., cloud, ML), strong US and global demand (business investment in technology), weaker USD, and more favorable technicals. S&P 500 Technology is expected to deliver superior growth while trades at market valuation. Also, the sector in aggregate holds ~$765 billion in overseas cash (or 15% of market cap), which they believe will be increasingly used for shareholder payouts (especially during market sell-offs) and could support a case for multiple re-rating, see Figure 6. In fact, S&P the sector has already announced $73b in buybacks YTD (or ~45% of total S&P 500 buyback announcements, see Figure 5) and are likely to announce additional programs during 1Q earnings season. However JP Morgan are Neutral on Tech given more favorable policy for domestic companies (e.g., lower taxes, deregulation, and potential infrastructure spending).

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European equities have joined the global relief rally (Eurostoxx +1.4%) seen between US and Asia overnight as trade tensions ease
content:
27th March 2018

  • European equities have joined the global relief rally (Eurostoxx +1.4%) seen between US and Asia overnight as trade tensions ease
  • Very choppy trade in the currency markets with month end flows/positioning in evidence, but far from one-way or clear cut
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US APIs, Fed’s Bostic and US 5yr Note Auction

ASIA

Asian stocks were positive across the board as the region took impetus from the gains on Wall St where stocks rebounded with a vengeance from the prior week’s worst performance in 2 years. The sharp recovery was spurred by easing trade war concerns after reports of US and China negotiating on trade and saw the largest percentage increase in all US majors since August 2015, while DJIA also gained by the most points in nearly a decade. ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.7%) were higher in which mining names and financials led Australia, while the Japanese benchmark outperformed as the index coat-tailed on gains in USD/JPY and following the testimony by former tax office chief Sagawa who declared there were no instructions made by PM Abe or his close circle to alter the documents related to the land sale scandal. Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) conformed to the upbeat tone as trade war concerns eased and as corporate financial results took centre stage in China, with the big 4 banks underpinned after AgBank beat estimates as it kicked off the earnings releases amongst China’s banking behemoths. Finally, 10yr JGBs were weaker amid the gains in riskier assets and with demand also shunned following a mixed 40yr auction.

Japan former tax agency chief Sagawa said there was no report to the PM's office of documents being altered and added that there were no instructions from PM Abe, his wife, Finance Minister Aso or their aides to doctor the documents. In related news, there were also comments from Finance Minister Aso that PM Abe’s office was not involved with document alterations in the controversial land sale. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 10bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2816 (Prev. 6.3193)

Chinese Industrial Profits YTD (Feb) Y/Y 16.1% (Prev. 21.0%). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Russian Deputy Foreign Minister warns of 'harsh' response to expulsion of diplomats from the US, but still open to cooperation (RIA)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Quarles (Voter, Neutral) said US economy is performing well and unemployment is at a low level, although he added that financial challenges remain for many households and communities. (Newswires)

Fed’s Mester (Voter, Hawk) said she sees further interest rate hikes this year and next despite seeing more slack, while Mester added that tariffs and NAFTA renegotiations pose risks to economic outlook. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said he supports plans to gradually raise interest rates, but uncertainty over how the economy would respond next year to tax cuts and increased government spending could complicate monetary policy. (WSJ)

ECB’s Vasiliauskas (Hawkish) expects more detailed talks on policy changes in June and agrees with market forecast for a mid-2019 rate hike. This follows ECB’s Weidmann yesterday, saying he expects a mid-2019 rate hike. (Newswires)

ECB's Liikanen (Neutral) says EZ inflation is sustainable when ECB's objective can be met without very accommodative monetary policy. He adds that the ECB needs patience as underlying inflation is lower than expected. (Newswires)

ECB’s Nowotny (Hawkish) believes asset purchases should be gradually reduce. Adding that If things continue as they are, they will be able to reduce asset purchases significantly and must decide by summer. Furthermore, stating we must be careful not to fall behind the curve. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

White House counsel's office is examining if loans made to Jared Kushner's family business which surpassed USD 500mln breached any criminal laws or ethics rules, according to reports which cited a letter dated last week. (Axios)

Five Star Movement studying ministerial offers to Northern League, this comes after Northern League’s leader Salvini and 5-Star Movement's chairman Di Maio discussed a potential plan for the Italian government. (La Stampa)

EQUITIES

European equities have joined the global relief rally (Eurostoxx +1.4%) seen between US and Asia overnight as trade tensions ease. In terms of sector specifics, materials (+2.0%) are the outperformers, enjoying a strong rebound from yesterday’s losses. Looking at individual movers, Casino (+3.4%) spiked at the open after its Monoprix chain has agreed to sell products on Amazon, GSK (+6.0%) is a top performer in the FTSE 100 after it announced to purchase a 36.5% stake in Novartis’ healthcare unit for USD 13bln. Elsewhere, Akzo Nobel (+3.0%) received a boost after Carlyle has won the bid to acquire the chemical arm unit for approx. EUR 10bln.

FX

Very choppy trade in the currency markets with month end flows/positioning in evidence, but far from one-way or clear cut. The Eur outperformed during early trade and was a broad gainer vs G10 counterparts with the marginal exception of the Chf as that cross traded sideways within a confined 1.1760-75 range. Eur/Usd extended gains beyond near term resistance around 1.2446 to circa 1.2475, while Eur/Gbp and Eur/Jpy got close to 0.8800 and 132.00 respectively on stops and buy orders that appeared to be fix-related. However, dovish ECB comments coincided with a loss of impetus and retreat in the single currency to the benefit of the Greenback and other peers, with a French bank noting 'strong' Dollar demand for month end re-balancing (according to Newswires, Credit Agricole). Indeed, the DXY managed to reclaim 89.000+ status, as Cable recoiled to the 1.4125 area from 1.4240 highs, Aud/Usd pulled back from 0.7750+ to 0.7715 and Nzd/Usd topped out around 0.7300 again. Usd/Cad bounced ahead of strong chart support at 1.2803 and the psychological 1.2800 level as the Loonie lost some of its NAFTA related positive momentum (after US reports that a ‘good’ deal is in the offing), while the Jpy continues to track overall risk sentiment and suffered on a sharp global stock market recovery – falling to 105.75 vs the Usd and testing resistance in the 105.70-75 zone (200 HMA).

FIXED INCOME

Technical and fundamental factors could be attributed to the recovery in core bonds, as interim downside chart supports/targets held, while ECB speakers have been mainly dovish, especially Liikanen that reiterated a possible QE extension beyond September if necessary. However, the turnaround seemed to start on Liffe with Gilts that have tested the water above 122.00 at 122.03 (+21 ticks vs -9 ticks at worst) and there are big month end extensions to justify the underlying bid, while Bunds have been up to 159.09 (+16 ticks vs -20 ticks at the low). US Treasuries still lagging after the big Wall St revival yesterday and ahead of more hefty supply.

COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures are flat after failing to breach the USD 66/bbl level to the upside ahead of this week’s inventory releases and with Russia’s Energy Minister reiterating it is too early to discuss an exit from the output cut deal. Elsewhere, spot gold is trading marginally lower as it tracks fluctuations in the dollar index, while fears of trade wars recede after yesterday’s reports of talks between US and China. In base metals, copper strengthened overnight amid the recovery in risk appetite and with upside spurred on the open of Chinese metals trade.

EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: European stocks are given a lift as trade war fears ease. Materials on the rebound.
content:
European equities have joined the global relief rally (Eurostoxx +1.4%) seen between US and Asia overnight as trade tensions ease. In terms of sector specifics, materials (+1.4%) are the outperformers, enjoying a strong rebound from yesterday’s losses. Looking at individual movers, Casino (+4.0%) spiked at the open after its Monoprix chain has agreed to sell products on Amazon, GSK (+4.7%) is a top performer in the FTSE 100 after it announced to purchase a 36.5% stake in Novartis’ healthcare unit for USD 13bln. Elsewhere, Akzo Nobel (+3.8%) received a boost after Carlyle has won the bid to acquire the chemical arm unit for approx. EUR 10bln.

Despite at least one bank model suggesting ‘strong’ Dollar demand for month end rebalancing, the Eur outperformed during the early part of Tuesday’s EU session and was a broad gainer vs G10 counterparts with the marginal exception of the Chf as that cross traded sideways within a confined 1.1760-75 range. Eur/Usd extended gains beyond near term resistance around 1.2446 to circa 1.2475, while Eur/Gbp and Eur/Jpy got close to 0.8800 and 132.00 respectively on stops and buy orders that appeared to be fix-related. However, dovish ECB comments coincided with a loss of impetus and retreat in the single currency to the benefit of the Greenback and other peers. Indeed, the DXY managed to reclaim 89.000+ status, albeit just, as Cable recoiled to the 1.4155 area from 1.4240 highs, Aud/Usd pulled back from 0.7750+ to 0.7720 and Nzd/Usd topped out around 0.7300 again. Usd/Cad bounced ahead of strong chart support at 1.2803 and the psychological 1.2800 level as the Loonie lost some of its NAFTA related positive momentum (after US reports that a ‘good’ deal is in the offing), while the Jpy continues to track overall risk sentiment and suffered on a sharp global stock market recovery – falling to 105.75 vs the Usd and testing resistance in the 105.70-75 zone (200 HMA).

Technical and fundamental factors could be attributed to the recovery in core bonds, as interim downside chart supports/targets held, while ECB speakers have been mainly dovish, especially Liikanen that reiterated a possible QE extension beyond September if necessary. However, the turnaround seemed to start on Liffe with Gilts that have tested the water above 122.00 at 122.03 (+21 ticks vs -9 ticks at worst) and there are big month end extensions to justify the underlying bid, while Bunds have been up to 159.09 (+16 ticks vs -20 ticks at the low). US Treasuries still lagging after the big Wall St revival yesterday and ahead of more hefty supply.

WTI crude futures are flat after failing to breach the USD 66/bbl level to the upside ahead of this week’s inventory releases and with Russia’s Energy Minister reiterating it is too early to discuss an exit from the output cut deal. Elsewhere, spot gold is trading flat as it tracks fluctuations in the dollar index, while fears of trade wars recede after yesterday’s reports of talks between US and China. In base metals, copper strengthened overnight amid the recovery in risk appetite and with upside spurred on the open of Chinese metals trade.

subject: Bunds: conceding ground again as risk sentiment rebounds markedly
content: As usual not much attention paid to German import price data despite a significant decline in both the m/m and y/y indices, with the core 10 year benchmark gapping down off the Eurex open on broader market sentiment and a sharp ramp up in risk appetite instead. The range so far has been 158.73-83 vs yesterday’s 158.93 close, and the short term technical picture has turned somewhat bearish again with sellers/bears looking at nearest downside supports again and recent session lows around 158.70 and then 158.55. From a fundamental standpoint German bonds may also be acknowledging the semi-recovery in Italian BTPs after Monday’s political fall-out, while on the data front Eurozone M3 and sentiment indicators could offer some direction ahead of the US open and 2nd batch of this week’s heavy Treasury/bill issuance.

US

* EQUITIES: SPX +2.72% at 2658, NDX +3.78% at 6753, DJI +2.84% at 24202

* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +2.85%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +1.38%, ENERGY (XLE): +1.80%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +3.16%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +2.10%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +2.40%, MATERIALS (XLB): +2.01%, TECH (XLK): +3.88%, TELECOMS (XTL): +0.95%, UTLITIES (XLU): +1.14%.

Overnight, Emini S&P 500 futures found support at the 200d SMA again, which – like in February – provided futs with a spring board. For most of the day, action was above the 2600 level, even when the risk-tone took a knock after the cash open. But the overall tone remained firm, as Trade War tensions ease following the US and China’s decision to begin negotiating trade, which led to a risk-on market tone. There were also some positive comments from trade advisor Navarro, who sounded constructive on NAFTA and trade negotiations. All sectors closed the day in the green being led by the technology sector, following Morgan Stanley raising its price target on Microsoft (MSFT) to a street high, and Intel (INTC) being upgraded at Raymond James. However, focus was firmly on Facebook (FB) after the FTC announced an open, non-public investigation on the company’s privacy practices. Since then, a Wells Fargo analyst came out with a note saying that the shares are now a buying opportunity with a price target of USD 230, which helped pare back today’s losses as they close positive.

DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks were positive across the board as the region took impetus from the gains on Wall St (largest gain since Aug’15)
content:
• Asian stocks were positive across the board as the region took impetus from the gains on Wall St (largest gain since Aug’15)
  • DXY-index is off its worst levels although still lacked any meaningful recovery from yesterday’s outflows
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US APIs, ECB’s Liikanen and Fed’s Bostic

ASIA

Asian stocks were positive across the board as the region took impetus from the gains on Wall St where stocks rebounded with a vengeance from the prior week’s worst performance in 2 years. The sharp recovery was spurred by easing trade war concerns after reports of US and China negotiating on trade and saw the largest percentage increase in all US majors since August 2015, while DJIA also gained by the most points in nearly a decade. ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.4%) were higher in which mining names and financials led Australia, while the Japanese benchmark outperformed as the index coat-tailed on gains in USD/JPY and following the testimony by former tax office chief Sagawa who declared there were no instructions made by PM Abe or his close circle to alter the documents related to the land sale scandal. Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) conformed to the upbeat tone as trade war concerns eased and as corporate financial results took centre stage in China, with the big 4 banks underpinned after AgBank beat estimates as it kicked off the earnings releases amongst China’s banking behemoths. Finally, 10yr JGBs were weaker amid the gains in riskier assets and with demand also shunned following a mixed 40yr auction.

Japan former tax agency chief Sagawa said there was no report to the PM's office of documents being altered and added that there were no instructions from PM Abe, his wife, Finance Minister Aso or their aides to doctor the documents. In related news, there were also comments from Finance Minister Aso that PM Abe’s office was not involved with document alterations in the controversial land sale. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 10bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2816 (Prev. 6.3193)

Chinese Industrial Profits YTD (Feb) Y/Y 16.1% (Prev. 21.0%). (Newswires)

FX

FX markets continued to lack any major catalysts overnight amid light data releases, which in turn kept risk sentiment as the main driving force. As such, safe-havens remained weaker with JPY taking the brunt of the rebound in stocks which helped USD/JPY and JPY-crosses extend on gains, with further support seen after Sagawa’s parliamentary testimony which denied PM Abe involvement in the document alterations. Elsewhere, the DXY-index is off its worst levels although still lacked any meaningful recovery from yesterday’s outflows which saw a breakdown attempt of the 89.00 level, while its major counterparts were relatively flat with EUR/USD and GBP/USD holding onto the recently reclaimed 1.2400 and 1.4200 handles respectively.


COMMODITIES

Commodities saw mild gains on what was a relatively quiet overnight session for the complex. Nonetheless, WTI crude futures were marginally higher and approached just shy of the USD 66.00/bbl level to the upside ahead of this week’s inventory releases and with Russia’s Energy Minister reiterating it is too early to discuss an exit from the output cut deal. Elsewhere, gold saw mild upside as the green back languished from the prior day’s losses, while copper strengthened amid the recovery in risk appetite and with upside spurred on the open of Chinese metals trade.

Russian Energy Minister Novak said it is too soon to start talking about an exit from OPEC oil output deal and noted that an exit should be gradual. (Newswires)

Iraqi oil minister said expects Basra terminal maintenance to lead to exports being cut by about 10mln barrels in April. (Newswires)

US President Trump is said to withdraw from nuclear agreement with Iran on May 12. (RTE)


US

Yields were up across the curve amid a firm risk tone, with the belly seeing most of the action, with yields on 10s up c.3bps to around 2.85%. The front end of the curve was up by c.2bps. The US is set to issue $109bln (ex-bills) in 2s/5s/7s/ and 2yr FRN this week, with net supply estimated around $43bln. The supply started off on a mediocre note with a sale of 2s that tailed by 0.4bps, and cover was slightly stronger than the previous. Perhaps the most interesting story was that it was digested well considering the Treasury + Bills issuance this week is set to come in just shy of $300bln. 10-year T-note futures settle 4+ ticks lower at 128-15.

Fed's Quarles (Voter, Neutral) said US economy is performing well and unemployment is at a low level, although he added that financial challenges remain for many households and communities. (Newswires)

Fed’s Mester (Voter, Hawk) said she sees further interest rate hikes this year and next despite seeing more slack, while Mester added that tariffs and NAFTA renegotiations pose risks to economic outlook. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer may announce a list of tariffs on China as soon as Tuesday. (CNBC)

White House counsel's office is examining if loans made to Jared Kushner's family business which surpassed USD 500mln breached any criminal laws or ethics rules, according to reports which cited a letter dated last week. (Axios)
